Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: Several users report intermittent errors that disrupt normal usage
Story:
I stare at my phone, thumb hovering over the call button. Mom’s text from earlier lingers in my mind: “Dad seems quiet lately. Everything’s okay, but can you call tonight?” I know what she’s really asking—she wants me to check in, to be the one who listens, who reassures. I want to be there for them, to ask if everything is really okay at home, to offer the support they expect from me as their child.

But my laptop screen is filled with error logs and urgent messages from QA. “Users are still getting the timeout bug,” one message reads. “Any update?” another pings. The pressure mounts; I’m the one who’s supposed to fix this, to make the app work, to keep the users happy. My team is waiting, the users are frustrated, and I know I can’t let this linger.

My heart pounds as I sit between the two worlds—my parents’ quiet need for comfort and my team’s urgent demand for solutions. I feel pulled apart, guilty for even hesitating, wishing I could be fully present for both. My finger trembles, caught between dialing home and diving back into code.
